text: The bulldog gets it done.  I can't say enough about this tool.  Its done everything I've asked it to do. From hammering through a 8 in slab, to drilling through  8 in block.Of course, I don't use it everyday like a contractor, but I'de imagine for that kind of use, I'de buy one of the bigger bosch hammers for everyday punishment.  The bits are somewhat pricey, but for good reason, they last!  You will only probably need to buy them once.For occasional to medium use,  this is a winner!

Despite the hefty price tag and prestigious name, this saw won't hold a blade! My first one wouldn't... and neither would the replacement Home Depot gave me. Nothing I did would make a blade stay in. Call to the factory elicited this comment: "Yeah, we get a lot of complaints about that."  Duh! Tried it one last time and -- the motor went out!  I finallly bought the top-of-the-line Craftsman (made by Bosch) and no such problems -- it's a honey.

My daughter began playing this game at age 6.  She will now play it with anyone who offers!  It is challenging and fun for adults as well.  The only downsides are that you need a fairly large, flat surface to create the tile patterns, and you need to be prepared to play for 30 minutes or more in order to finish a full game.  If you bump the table and jar the tiles, it can really lead to chaos if the game is fairly far-along.  Overall, however, I highly recommend it, even for adults.

We've played a few games of Fluxx and while it is easy to learn and play, it just isn't a very exciting game. The idea that the goal continually changes is neat, but it continually changes so often you really have no way to strategize. It ends up coming down to holding cards in your hand that you can't play so another player won't win, until you have to play something to end the game. Thankfully it wasn't very expensive. This is my first Fluxx style game but I assume all of them are very similar in nature.

This game was very poorly made...it's really boring, because all you do is walk around and throw stuff at things. All the enemies are exactly the same, there's never any health, and 100 health points aren't enough, because the health goes down too fast. The sight of range is ridiculous because half the screen is nothing but fog, and it all just draws in as you walk ahead, making it hard to see enemies. I do like seeing the familiar South Park characters in 3D, the game is very funny, and the weapons are hilarious! But still, I wouldn't buy it. Rent at most.

This was an amazing game when I first got it... a million years ago or so.  Funny thing is, they were talking about Diablo 2 in developement back then, but I didn't see it for at least another 2 and a half years...If you happen to be running a computer that is older than dirt, go ahead and buy this game, I think it is great, but it is way past it's time.  As a matter of fact, I think I saw someone playing it the last time I was in Amish country.

The bulldog performs admirably in all tasks I have assigned it, from breaking through an 8-inch slab to penetrating an 8-inch block. Although I don't use it as frequently as a professional contractor, I would recommend investing in one of the larger Bosch hammers for enduring daily hardship. The drill bits may be somewhat expensive, but they are well worth the cost considering their durability. In all likelihood, you will only have to purchase them once. For intermittent to moderate use, this tool is undoubtedly a top choice.

There is no doubt that the bulldog is a reliable tool. I cannot emphasize enough how impressed I am with its versatility. It has successfully tackled every task I've thrown its way, whether it be demolishing an 8-inch slab or drilling through an 8-inch block. While I don't utilize it on a daily basis like a professional contractor, I would suggest opting for one of the larger Bosch hammers for heavy-duty, everyday usage. The drill bits may be slightly expensive, but they are certainly worth the investment as they have exceptional longevity. Most likely, you will only need to purchase them once. For occasional to moderate use, this tool is the ultimate winner.

The bulldog is a tool that consistently gets the job done. I cannot emphasize enough how effective it has been in all my tasks. It has surpassed my expectations by effortlessly hammering through an 8-inch slab and drilling through an 8-inch block. Although I don't implement it in my daily work like a professional contractor, I would imagine that for such intensive usage, it would be wise to invest in one of the larger Bosch hammers capable of withstanding daily punishment. The drill bits may be a bit pricey, but their longevity justifies the cost. Chances are, you will only need to purchase them once. This tool is the perfect choice for occasional to moderate use.

The bulldog consistently delivers outstanding results. I cannot praise it enough as a tool. It has successfully accomplished every task I have assigned, whether it involved breaking through an 8-inch slab or drilling through an 8-inch block. However, since I do not use it on a daily basis like a professional contractor, I recommend considering one of the larger Bosch hammers for everyday use that endures heavy punishment. Despite its expensive cost and reputable brand, this saw fails to securely hold a blade. Both the original one I had and the replacement provided by Home Depot had the same issue. No matter what I tried, the blade would not stay in place. When I reached out to the manufacturer, they acknowledged receiving numerous complaints about it. As if to add insult to injury, the motor eventually stopped working after one last attempt. In the end, I opted for the high-end Craftsman saw, which is manufactured by Bosch, and it works flawlessly.

This saw, despite its hefty price tag and prestigious name, proved to be quite a disappointment when it came to keeping the blade in place. Neither the first one I had nor the replacement I received from Home Depot managed to solve this problem. No matter what troubleshooting attempts I made, I couldn't stop the blade from coming loose. A call to the factory only confirmed that they had received numerous complaints about this issue. And just when I thought things couldn't get worse, the motor eventually gave out. This forced me to purchase the top-of-the-line Craftsman saw, which is made by Bosch, and thankfully, it has proved to be a reliable investment.

Despite its expensive price and esteemed reputation, this saw falls short in terms of blade retention. It was only then that I decided to splurge on the top-of-the-line Craftsman saw, which is expertly crafted by Bosch, and fortunately, I have encountered no such obstacles as it operates flawlessly.

At the age of 6, my daughter started playing this game and now she willingly plays it with anyone who proposes. It offers a challenging and enjoyable experience for both adults and children alike. The only drawbacks are that you require a reasonably spacious and level surface to construct the tile patterns, and you should be ready to engage in a game lasting at least 30 minutes to complete a full round. If the table is accidentally disturbed and the tiles are jolted, it can cause significant disruption, particularly if the game has progressed significantly. Nonetheless, I wholeheartedly recommend it, even for adults.

When my daughter reached the age of 6, she embarked on her journey of playing this game. Presently, she is willing to play this game with anyone who extends the invitation. The game poses a challenge and provides amusement not only for children but also for adults. However, there are a few drawbacks to consider. Firstly, you will need a considerably spacious and level surface in order to arrange the tile patterns. Additionally, you should allocate at least 30 minutes or more to complete an entire game. Disturbing the table or accidental jostling of the tiles can create chaos, especially when the game is well-progressed. Nevertheless, I highly recommend this game, even for adults.

Although Fluxx is simple to understand and play, it lacks excitement. The constantly changing goal is interesting, but it changes so frequently that strategic planning is impossible. Ultimately, the game becomes about holding onto cards to prevent another player from winning until you're forced to play something to end it. Fortunately, it didn't cost much. This is my first experience with a Fluxx-style game, but I assume they are all quite similar in nature.

Despite being easy to learn and play, Fluxx fails to provide much excitement. The concept of the ever-changing goal is intriguing, but it changes so rapidly that strategic thinking becomes impossible. Eventually, the game boils down to hoarding cards in your hand to prevent another player from winning, until you're forced to play something to end it. Fortunately, it wasn't a costly purchase. As my first Fluxx-style game, I assume they all share a similar nature.

We've engaged in a few rounds of Fluxx, and while it is a simple and accessible game, it lacks excitement. The idea of constantly shifting goals is interesting, but the rapidity of the changes hampers strategic planning. Ultimately, the gameplay reduces to holding onto cards that you can't play in order to hinder other players' progress, until you're compelled to play something to conclude the game. Thankfully, it wasn't an expensive investment. As my initial experience with a Fluxx-style game, I presume they are all alike in nature.

Our few sessions of Fluxx highlighted its easy-to-learn and play nature, but it ultimately falls short in terms of excitement. While the concept of ever-changing goals is intriguing, the frequency of these changes impedes any strategic thinking. In the end, the game revolves around hoarding cards that you can't play to prevent others from winning until you're forced to play something to conclude the game. Luckily, it didn't require a significant financial commitment. This being my inaugural experience with a Fluxx-style game, I assume they all possess a similar character.

The game's poor quality makes it extremely dull since the only activity involves aimlessly wandering around and throwing projectiles. Moreover, all the enemies lack variety, there is never any health available, and the allocated 100 health points prove insufficient due to their rapid depletion.

The game's construction is highly inadequate, resulting in a monotonous experience where one merely navigates through the environment and hurls objects at objects. Additionally, every antagonist encountered is indistinguishably alike, lacking any form of restorative health, while the allotted 100 health points prove woefully inadequate as they swiftly diminish.

Due to its subpar development, this game proves to be exceedingly unexciting, as it solely revolves around aimlessly strolling and launching objects at targets. Moreover, the absence of diversity among adversaries, the perpetual absence of health replenishment, and the inadequacy of the provided 100 health points intensify the dissatisfaction.

The underwhelming craftsmanship of this game renders it extremely tedious, for the gameplay primarily consists of monotonous walking and throwing actions. Furthermore, the repeated appearance of identical enemies, the perpetual lack of health restoration, and the insufficient allocation of 100 health points contribute to the game's unsatisfactory nature.

This game's shoddy production quality makes it dreadfully uninteresting since the sole objective involves aimlessly moving around and hurling projectiles. Additionally, the clonesque nature of the opponents, the perpetual absence of health pickups, and the inadequate allocation of 100 health points intensify the game's overall dissatisfaction.

The game's woefully inadequate construction results in an incredibly monotonous experience wherein players are confined to aimlessly roaming and flinging objects. Furthermore, the consistent presence of identical adversaries, the perpetual absence of health replenishment, and the insufficient allocation of 100 health points all contribute to the overall dissatisfaction with the game.

When I first acquired this game ages ago, it truly impressed me. Ironically, during that era, there were talks about the development of Diablo 2, although I didn't get my hands on it until a good two and a half years later. If you happen to own a computer ancient as dirt, go ahead and purchase this game; I find it exceptional, although it is undeniably outdated. In fact, I recall seeing someone playing it the last time I visited Amish country.

This game was absolutely incredible when I first obtained it... perhaps a million years ago. It's funny how they were discussing Diablo 2 in the works during that time, yet it took me another two and a half years until I finally experienced it. If by any chance you are using a computer older than dirt, I highly recommend buying this game - I believe it is fantastic, although it is well beyond its prime. Interestingly enough, I even saw someone playing it on my recent visit to Amish country.
